data.text: Park Tools 10.3 Repair Stand OR Feedback Sports Pro Elite Stand?

Has anyone used both the Park Tools 10.3 repair stand and the Feedback Sports Pro Elite stand and have a favorite? I have some gift cards I’m going to combine and have decided on these 2 models. Both have their positives and criticisms. Both identical price and same availability. Will be used for my cross bike, commuter, and probably mtb’s in the future. Park Tool 10.3: - 2 leg design (may be better on flat ground), heavier at 21 lbs, foldable, great reviews, 39-57 inches working height, 80 lb limit Feedback Sports Pro Elite: -3 leg design (may be better on uneven ground), lighter at 13 lbs, foldable, great reviews, 42-71 inches working height, 85 lb limit
I've got the park tool one but if I bought again I'd go feedback sports tbh
data.author: Cameron Jones

data.text: I am very happy with my Feedback sports pro elite stand. I suspect they are pretty similar, well made premium brand stands. Toss a coin.
data.author: Jim Hislop

data.text: I used one cheap two legged bike stand bought from Amazon, was pretty happy with it. This one's more expensive so must be really good quality and sturdy. In this case I would go for feedback sports, three legs probably should give more stability and easier to place on uneven ground. But both are decent!
data.author: Igr Go

data.text: Look at the weight limit of each one would be a criteria for me. My Feedback has a plastic knob that started to split a bit.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: I have the Feedback and like it a lot. The quick release does it for me.
data.author: Xaver von Treyer

data.text: I like the feedback stands a lot. They fold up pretty small and easy to tuck away in your car for traveling etc, 3 legged is sturdy, height is adjustable.
data.author: Jon Turner

data.text: I have both and prefer the Feedback.
data.author: Chris Boling

data.text: Park tool, I find the 2 leg design works better (has more space) then the 3 leg.
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I’ve used both and I’d probably go feedback because of how small it packs up and how portable it is.
data.author: Jeremy LaMothe

data.text: I have and prefer the 2 legged design of the Park. Very stable and I like that you can use it in a smaller footprint or closer to a wall. However, it doesn’t fold up as compact as others.
data.author: Dan Sweeney

data.text: I am very happy with the Bikehand one I got from Amazon.
data.author: Andre Velloso

data.text:
- this is the one I got: https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B00D9B7OKQ/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Bikehand Bike Repair Stand Home Portable Bicycle Mechanics Workstand Maintenance
amazon.ca
data.author: Andre Velloso

data.text: It looks similar in sturdiness as the Park Tool. I do not like the red one picture to be honest.
data.author: Andre Velloso

data.text: appreciate your input
data.author: Jonathan Thornburg

data.text: - I just checked and they say, max load is 55lbs... Less than what you posted for the other 2. But a lot for a bike.
data.author: Andre Velloso

data.text: I had a Feedback knockoff and went to the Park Tool 10.3. Much prefer the two legged setup and the clamp mechanism for my aero seatpost.
data.author: Dan O'Brien

data.text: I think it depends on how "portable" you'll need it to be. The Park is heavier and better if it's gonna mainly stay home in your basement or garage whereas the Feedback is lighter and quicker to pack down if it's gonna be on the road w/ you for trips and events.
data.author: Mike Clark

data.text: I have to admit I bought the Aldi special for £25, it’s brilliant
data.author: Rob Jones

data.text: I went with feedback for portability but it's way to light and unstable. So I got the park tool pro. It's so much better!
data.author: Sean Gates

data.text: Argh, I’m still torn but thanks everyone for your input. I ordered the feedback pro elite and am already second guessing myself. REI has a pretty good return policy so I can always exchange. They just put the feedback on clearance (save $70) and I’m a sucker for a deal. Thanks everyone!!
data.author: Jonathan Thornburg

data.text: I never use my feedback stand lol
data.author: Sean Gates

data.text: not helping 😋
data.author: Jonathan Thornburg

data.text: Yea. Feedback. It's more stable. Packs compactly.
data.author: Berne Broudy

data.text: I just ordered the 10.3 from Jenson a few hours ago... they had 20% off and free 3 day shipping to Canada (with no extra fees/duties etc.). I considered the 10.2, but there's some issues... and the 9.3 but ordered the quick release etc. of this one. My current stand had 4 legs and is a bit gift with heavier bikes. Gets annoying after a while. I like this 2 leg setup.
data.author: Jeremy Schwab

data.text: I like my feedback. All aluminum, no steel parts that’ll rust. And the clamps and extending bits are also aluminum.
data.author: Jeffrey Ahn

data.text: The quick release on the pro is genuinely fantastic. It's less stable at full extension, which sucks for tall folks, but the clamp more than makes up for it.
data.author: Nicholas Prewitt

data.text: Been using the PCS 10.3 for a couple of years, only issue is that the head gets stuck and is hard to rotate
data.author: Gerry Askefalk
